comments: report_config allows for updating markdown reports without modifying code.
there are five sections: xkeylabels, xkeysources, introduction,, bykeys, and plotopts
xkeylabels translate variable names to pretty labels.
xkeysources translate variable names to data source pretty names.
introduction items have the form content, style, xkeys.
- content is what should be shown.
- style must be a valid Word style https://python-docx.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/styles-understanding.html Content is what should be shown.
- xkeys is a list of xkeys where this should be used (null=all).
bykeys has a list of plot suffixes to include in the report in order.
- suffixes are typically bycld, byweek, etc
plotopts is a list of dictionaries where each dictionary has:
- a caption template to be used in the report,
- a figure width as a fraction of page,
introduction: This report has plots organized by analysis region for {source} {spc}. All data uses teh version 3 (v3) TEMPO data products. Except when evaluating the effect of cloud fraction, all TEMPO data has been filtered for effective cloud fraction less than 0.15 based on SAO recommendation at the GeoXO ACX May meeting. All data has also been filtered for high quality and having solar zenith angle less than 70 degrees
TropOMI intersections are any TropOMI pixel that overlaps a TEMPO pixel. Statistics (mean, std, quantiles) are all based on all intersections within the region.
TEMPO totNO2 is the sum of tropospheric and stratspheric vertical columns.
TropOMI totNO2 is the sum of tropospheric and stratspheric vertical columns.

Pandora intersections are any TEMPO pixel that overlaps a 0.03 degree radius. Only intersections within 15 minutes of a TEMPO measurement are used. Statistics (mean, std, quantiles) are all based on each +-15 minute period or pooled data.

AirNow intersections are any TEMPO pixel that overlaps a monitor location. AirNow measurements integrated over an hour, and are compared to any TEMPO measurement within that hour. Statistics (mean, std, quantiles) are all based on hourly pairs or pairs pooled within the Ozone non-attainment bounding box.
There is a major section for all sites and then a section for each site. Each section shows comparisons:
by solar zenith angle and local standard hour,
by location (only for all sites section)
For TropOMI, the by location figures are split to show Pandorastations in one figure and Nonattainment AReas in another

TropOMI intersections include both Pandora locations and Nonattainment Areas (NAA). However, the NAA are larger and include more pixels. The NAA have more area in the West, so the time-series including all sites are skewed by the western performance. By comparison, the Pandora are more in the East, so the time-series are any TropOMI pixel that overlaps a TEMPO pixel. Statistics (mean, std, quantiles) are all based on all intersections within the region.
Within each section, there are three types of plots:
box plots showing the inter-quartile range,
scatter plots summarizing the ability to characterize variation, and
Mean Bias (MB), Mean Absolute Bias (MAB), and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE)
MB, MAB, and RMSE are also shown as percents by normalizing to the reference mean
Use section headers to navigate by Headings to a specific analysis region.

plotopts.caption: Box (25%, 50%, 75%) and whisker (min/max) plots for by {bykey} at {label}.

Scatter plot medians by {bykey} at {label} with linear regression fit. Each point has all pixels in a {bykey} and error bars represent the 25% to 75% range of those pixels.

Scatter plot medians by {bykey} at {label} with linear regression fit Pandora. Each point has all pixels in a {bykey} and error bars represent the 25% to 75% range of those pixels.
